focus_skills: Nonlinear equations in one variable and systems of equations in two variables
Systems of 2 linear equations in 2 variables

questions.skill: Linear equations in one variable
questions.question: The equation <math><mi>x</mi><mo>+</mo><mn>4</mn><mo>=</mo><mn>12</mn></math> is equivalent to which of the following?
questions.explanation: Subtract 4 from both sides of the equation to yield <math><mi>x</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>8</mn></math>.
questions.score_improvement_tip: Practice isolating variables by performing inverse operations on both sides of the equation.

questions.skill: Nonlinear equations in one variable and systems of equations in two variables
questions.question: What is the positive solution to <math><mo>|</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>-</mo><mn>5</mn><mo>|</mo><mo>=</mo><mn>3</mn></math>?
questions.explanation: The equation <math><mo>|</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>-</mo><mn>5</mn><mo>|</mo><mo>=</mo><mn>3</mn></math> yields <math><mi>x</mi><mo>-</mo><mn>5</mn><mo>=</mo><mn>3</mn></math> or <math><mi>x</mi><mo>-</mo><mn>5</mn><mo>=</mo><mo>-</mo><mn>3</mn></math>. Solving gives <math><mi>x</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>8</mn></math> or <math><mi>x</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>2</mn></math>. The positive solution greater than 5 is 8.
questions.score_improvement_tip: Remember that absolute value equations produce two cases: one positive and one negative.

questions.skill: Linear inequalities in 1 or 2 variables
questions.question: Which inequality is equivalent to <math><mn>4</mn><mi>x</mi><mo>-</mo><mn>8</mn><mo>></mo><mn>12</mn></math>?
questions.explanation: Add 8 to both sides: <math><mn>4</mn><mi>x</mi><mo>></mo><mn>20</mn></math>. Divide by 4: <math><mi>x</mi><mo>></mo><mn>5</mn></math>.
questions.score_improvement_tip: When dividing inequalities by positive numbers, the inequality sign remains the same.

questions.skill: Nonlinear equations in one variable and systems of equations in two variables
questions.question: How many distinct real solutions does the equation <math><msup><mi>x</mi><mn>2</mn></msup><mo>-</mo><mn>6</mn><mi>x</mi><mo>+</mo><mn>9</mn><mo>=</mo><mn>0</mn></math> have?
questions.explanation: The discriminant is <math><msup><mn>6</mn><mn>2</mn></msup><mo>-</mo><mn>4</mn><mo>(</mo><mn>1</mn><mo>)</mo><mo>(</mo><mn>9</mn><mo>)</mo><mo>=</mo><mn>36</mn><mo>-</mo><mn>36</mn><mo>=</mo><mn>0</mn></math>, so there is exactly one real solution.
questions.score_improvement_tip: Use the discriminant to determine the number of real solutions for quadratic equations.

questions.skill: Nonlinear equations in one variable and systems of equations in two variables
questions.question_chart_svg: <svg width='400' height='300' viewBox='0 0 400 300' xmlns='http://www.w3.org/2000/svg'><rect width='400' height='300' fill='white' /><line x1='50' y1='250' x2='350' y2='250' stroke='black' stroke-width='2' /><line x1='50' y1='250' x2='50' y2='50' stroke='black' stroke-width='2' /><path d='M50 250 Q200 50 350 250' stroke='blue' fill='none' stroke-width='2' /><line x1='100' y1='250' x2='300' y2='150' stroke='red' stroke-width='2' /></svg>
questions.question_chart_description: A parabola opening upwards and a straight line intersecting it at two points.
questions.question: The graphs of a quadratic equation and a linear equation are shown in the xy-plane. How many solutions does the system have?
questions.explanation: The parabola and line intersect at two distinct points, so the system has two solutions.
questions.score_improvement_tip: Count the intersection points of graphs to determine the number of solutions in a system.

questions.skill: Nonlinear equations in one variable and systems of equations in two variables
questions.question: <math><mi>y</mi><mo>=</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>-</mo><mn>2</mn></math> <math><mi>y</mi><mo>=</mo><msup><mi>x</mi><mn>2</mn></msup><mo>-</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>-</mo><mn>6</mn></math> If <math><mo>(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>,</mo><mi>y</mi><mo>)</mo></math> is a solution to the system, which could be the value of <math><mi>x</mi></math>?
questions.explanation: Set equal: <math><mi>x</mi><mo>-</mo><mn>2</mn><mo>=</mo><msup><mi>x</mi><mn>2</mn></msup><mo>-</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>-</mo><mn>6</mn></math>. Rearrange: <math><msup><mi>x</mi><mn>2</mn></msup><mo>-</mo><mn>2</mn><mi>x</mi><mo>-</mo><mn>4</mn><mo>=</mo><mn>0</mn></math>. Solutions are <math><mi>x</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>1</mn><mo>±</mo><msqrt><mn>5</mn></msqrt></math>. Testing options, only 3 satisfies approximately.
questions.score_improvement_tip: Substitute and solve the resulting quadratic to find x-values in systems.

questions.skill: Nonlinear equations in one variable and systems of equations in two variables
questions.question: What values satisfy <math><msup><mi>x</mi><mn>2</mn></msup><mo>-</mo><mn>4</mn><mi>x</mi><mo>-</mo><mn>5</mn><mo>=</mo><mn>0</mn></math>?
questions.explanation: Using quadratic formula: <math><mi>x</mi><mo>=</mo><mfrac><mn>4</mn><mn>2</mn></mfrac><mo>±</mo><msqrt><mfrac><mn>16</mn><mn>4</mn></mfrac><mo>+</mo><mn>5</mn></msqrt></math> = <math><mn>2</mn><mo>±</mo><msqrt><mn>9</mn></msqrt></math> = <math><mn>5</mn></math> or <math><mo>-</mo><mn>1</mn></math>.
questions.score_improvement_tip: Factor quadratics or use the formula to find roots accurately.

questions.skill: Systems of 2 linear equations in 2 variables
questions.question: Solve the system: <math><mn>2</mn><mi>x</mi><mo>+</mo><mi>y</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>7</mn></math>, <math><mi>x</mi><mo>-</mo><mn>3</mn><mi>y</mi><mo>=</mo><mo>-</mo><mn>14</mn></math>. What is <math><mi>x</mi></math>?
questions.explanation: Multiply first by 3: <math><mn>6</mn><mi>x</mi><mo>+</mo><mn>3</mn><mi>y</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>21</mn></math>. Add to second: <math><mn>7</mn><mi>x</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>7</mn></math>. Thus x=1.
questions.score_improvement_tip: Use elimination by multiplying equations to cancel variables.

questions.skill: Percentages
questions.question: If 20% of a number is 50, what is 30% of the number?
questions.explanation: The number is <math><mn>50</mn><mo>/</mo><mn>0.2</mn><mo>=</mo><mn>250</mn></math>. 30% is <math><mn>0.3</mn><mo>×</mo><mn>250</mn><mo>=</mo><mn>75</mn></math>.
questions.score_improvement_tip: Find the whole first when given a percentage part.

questions.skill: Nonlinear equations in one variable and systems of equations in two variables
questions.question: The system <math><mi>y</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>2</mn><mi>x</mi><mo>+</mo><mn>3</mn></math>, <math><mi>y</mi><mo>=</mo><msup><mi>x</mi><mn>2</mn></msup><mo>+</mo><mi>x</mi></math> has two solutions. What is the sum of the x-values?
questions.explanation: Set equal: <math><msup><mi>x</mi><mn>2</mn></msup><mo>+</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>2</mn><mi>x</mi><mo>+</mo><mn>3</mn></math>. Rearrange: <math><msup><mi>x</mi><mn>2</mn></msup><mo>-</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>-</mo><mn>3</mn><mo>=</mo><mn>0</mn></math>. Sum of roots is 1.
questions.score_improvement_tip: Use the sum of roots from the quadratic coefficient for quick calculation.

questions.skill: Nonlinear equations in one variable and systems of equations in two variables
questions.question: In the system <math><mi>y</mi><mo>=</mo><mi>k</mi><mi>x</mi><mo>+</mo><mn>1</mn></math>, <math><mi>y</mi><mo>=</mo><msup><mi>x</mi><mn>2</mn></msup><mo>+</mo><mn>2</mn><mi>x</mi><mo>+</mo><mi>c</mi></math>, for positive constant k=2, the system has exactly one solution. What is <math><mi>c</mi></math>?
questions.explanation: Set equal: <math><msup><mi>x</mi><mn>2</mn></msup><mo>+</mo><mn>2</mn><mi>x</mi><mo>+</mo><mi>c</mi><mo>=</mo><mi>k</mi><mi>x</mi><mo>+</mo><mn>1</mn></math>. Rearrange: <math><msup><mi>x</mi><mn>2</mn></msup><mo>+</mo><mo>(</mo><mn>2</mn><mo>-</mo><mi>k</mi><mo>)</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>+</mo><mo>(</mo><mi>c</mi><mo>-</mo><mn>1</mn><mo>)</mo><mo>=</mo><mn>0</mn></math>. For one solution, discriminant zero: <math><mo>(</mo><mn>2</mn><mo>-</mo><mi>k</mi><msup><mo>)</mo><mn>2</mn></msup><mo>-</mo><mn>4</mn><mo>(</mo><mi>c</mi><mo>-</mo><mn>1</mn><mo>)</mo><mo>=</mo><mn>0</mn></math>. For k=2, this yields c=1.
questions.score_improvement_tip: Set discriminant to zero for exactly one real solution in quadratics.

questions.skill: Nonlinear equations in one variable and systems of equations in two variables
questions.question: The equation <math><mfrac><mn>1</mn><mi>a</mi></mfrac><mo>+</mo><mfrac><mn>1</mn><mi>b</mi></mfrac><mo>=</mo><mfrac><mn>1</mn><mi>c</mi></mfrac></math> relates positive a, b, c. Express c in terms of a and b.
questions.explanation: Common denominator: <math><mfrac><mi>b</mi><mrow><mi>a</mi><mi>b</mi></mrow></mfrac><mo>+</mo><mfrac><mi>a</mi><mrow><mi>a</mi><mi>b</mi></mrow></mfrac><mo>=</mo><mfrac><mn>1</mn><mi>c</mi></mfrac></math>, so <math><mfrac><mrow><mi>a</mi><mo>+</mo><mi>b</mi></mrow><mrow><mi>a</mi><mi>b</mi></mrow></mfrac><mo>=</mo><mfrac><mn>1</mn><mi>c</mi></mfrac></math>. Thus <math><mi>c</mi><mo>=</mo><mfrac><mrow><mi>a</mi><mi>b</mi></mrow><mrow><mi>a</mi><mo>+</mo><mi>b</mi></mrow></mfrac></math>.
questions.score_improvement_tip: Combine fractions to solve for one variable in terms of others.

questions.skill: Nonlinear equations in one variable and systems of equations in two variables
questions.question: The graph of <math><mi>y</mi><mo>=</mo><msup><mi>x</mi><mn>2</mn></msup><mo>-</mo><mn>4</mn><mi>x</mi><mo>+</mo><mn>3</mn></math> intersects <math><mi>y</mi><mo>=</mo><mi>k</mi></math> at one point. What is k?
questions.explanation: Vertex at <math><mi>x</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>2</mn></math>, <math><mi>y</mi><mo>=</mo><mo>-</mo><mn>1</mn></math>. For one intersection, k = -1.
questions.score_improvement_tip: Find the vertex for minimum or maximum to determine tangent horizontal line.

questions.skill: Nonlinear equations in one variable and systems of equations in two variables
questions.question: What is the sum of solutions to <math><mo>|</mo><mn>2</mn><mi>x</mi><mo>-</mo><mn>6</mn><mo>|</mo><mo>=</mo><mn>4</mn></math>?
questions.explanation: Cases: <math><mn>2</mn><mi>x</mi><mo>-</mo><mn>6</mn><mo>=</mo><mn>4</mn></math> → <math><mi>x</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>5</mn></math>; <math><mn>2</mn><mi>x</mi><mo>-</mo><mn>6</mn><mo>=</mo><mo>-</mo><mn>4</mn></math> → <math><mi>x</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>1</mn></math>. Sum = 6.
questions.score_improvement_tip: Solve both cases for absolute value and add solutions if required.

questions.skill: Right triangles and trigonometry
questions.question_chart_svg: <svg width='400' height='300' viewBox='0 0 400 300' xmlns='http://www.w3.org/2000/svg'><rect width='400' height='300' fill='white' /><line x1='50' y1='250' x2='310' y2='250' stroke='black' stroke-width='2' /><line x1='310' y1='250' x2='310' y2='100' stroke='black' stroke-width='2' /><line x1='50' y1='250' x2='310' y2='100' stroke='black' stroke-width='2' /><path d='M310 230 L290 230 L290 250' fill='none' stroke='black' stroke-width='1.5' /><path d='M90 250 A 40 40 0 0 0 85 228' stroke='black' fill='none' /><text x='100' y='245' font-family='serif' font-size='16'>30°</text><text x='170' y='170' font-family='serif' font-size='16'>10</text></svg>
questions.question_chart_description: A right-angled triangle with the right angle at the bottom right. The angle at the bottom left is labeled 30 degrees. The hypotenuse (the diagonal side) is labeled 10.
questions.question: In the right triangle shown, one angle is <math xmlns='http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML'><mn>30</mn><mo>°</mo></math> and the hypotenuse is <math xmlns='http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML'><mn>10</mn></math>. What is the length of the opposite side?
questions.explanation: In a right triangle, the side opposite the <math xmlns='http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML'><mn>30</mn><mo>°</mo></math> angle is equal to half the length of the hypotenuse. Since the hypotenuse is <math xmlns='http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML'><mn>10</mn></math>, the opposite side is <math xmlns='http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML'><mn>10</mn><mo>×</mo><mi>sin</mi><mo>(</mo><mn>30</mn><mo>°</mo><mo>)</mo><mo>=</mo><mn>5</mn></math>.
questions.explanation_chart_svg: <svg width='400' height='300' viewBox='0 0 400 300' xmlns='http://www.w3.org/2000/svg'><rect width='400' height='300' fill='white' /><line x1='50' y1='250' x2='310' y2='250' stroke='black' stroke-width='2' /><line x1='310' y1='250' x2='310' y2='100' stroke='red' stroke-width='3' /><line x1='50' y1='250' x2='310' y2='100' stroke='black' stroke-width='2' /><path d='M310 230 L290 230 L290 250' fill='none' stroke='black' stroke-width='1.5' /><text x='100' y='245' font-family='serif' font-size='16'>30°</text><text x='170' y='170' font-family='serif' font-size='16'>10</text><text x='320' y='180' fill='red' font-family='serif' font-size='16'>Opposite = ?</text></svg>
questions.explanation_chart_description: The same triangle with the vertical side (opposite to the 30-degree angle) highlighted in red to indicate it is the side being solved for.
questions.score_improvement_tip: Remember the special right triangle ratios (30-60-90): The sides are in the ratio <math xmlns='http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML'><mn>1</mn><mo>:</mo><msqrt><mn>3</mn></msqrt><mo>:</mo><mn>2</mn></math>.

questions.skill: Two-variable data: models and scatter-plots
questions.question: A scatterplot shows a linear trend with equation y = 3x + 5. If r^2 = 0.81, what is r?
questions.explanation: r = sqrt(0.81) = 0.9, assuming positive correlation.
questions.score_improvement_tip: The correlation coefficient is the square root of r-squared for linear models.

questions.skill: Equivalent expressions
questions.question: Which of the following expressions is equivalent to <math xmlns='http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML'><msup><mi>x</mi><mn>2</mn></msup><mo>-</mo><mn>9</mn><mi>x</mi><mi>y</mi><mo>+</mo><mn>20</mn><msup><mi>y</mi><mn>2</mn></msup></math>?
questions.explanation:
To factor the quadratic expression x2-9xy+20y2, we look for two numbers that satisfy two conditions:
1. They multiply to the coefficient of the last term (20).
2. They add up to the coefficient of the middle term (-9).

**Step 1: Check factors of 20.**
Possible pairs: (1,20), (2,10), (4,5).

**Step 2: Check signs.**
Since the product is positive (+20) and the sum is negative (-9), both numbers must be negative.
Test: (-4)+(-5)=-9 and (-4)×(-5)=20.

**Step 3: Write the factored form.**
The expression factors as (x-4y)(x-5y).
questions.score_improvement_tip: When factoring a quadratic like x^2 + bx + c, find two numbers that multiply to 'c' and add to 'b'. If 'c' is positive and 'b' is negative, both numbers are negative.

questions.skill: Circles
questions.question: A circle has equation <math><mo>(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>-</mo><mn>3</mn><msup><mo>)</mo><mn>2</mn></msup><mo>+</mo><mo>(</mo><mi>y</mi><mo>+</mo><mn>2</mn><msup><mo>)</mo><mn>2</mn></msup><mo>=</mo><mn>16</mn></math>. What is the radius?
questions.explanation: Standard form shows radius squared is 16, so radius 4.
questions.score_improvement_tip: Identify radius from square root of constant in circle equation.

questions.skill: Nonlinear functions
questions.question: Consider the quadratic function <math xmlns='http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML'><mi>f</mi><mo>(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>)</mo><mo>=</mo><msup><mi>x</mi><mn>2</mn></msup><mo>+</mo><mn>4</mn><mi>x</mi><mo>+</mo><mn>4</mn></math>. At which value of <math xmlns='http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML'><mi>x</mi></math> does the function achieve its minimum?
questions.explanation: The function is a quadratic in the form <math xmlns='http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML'><mi>f</mi><mo>(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>)</mo><mo>=</mo><mi>a</mi><msup><mi>x</mi><mn>2</mn></msup><mo>+</mo><mi>b</mi><mi>x</mi><mo>+</mo><mi>c</mi></math>, where <math xmlns='http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML'><mi>a</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>1</mn></math>, <math xmlns='http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML'><mi>b</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>4</mn></math>, and <math xmlns='http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML'><mi>c</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>4</mn></math>. Because <math xmlns='http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML'><mi>a</mi><mo>></mo><mn>0</mn></math>, the parabola opens upward, meaning the vertex represents the minimum value. The x-coordinate of the vertex is calculated as <math xmlns='http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML'><mi>x</mi><mo>=</mo><mo>-</mo><mfrac><mi>b</mi><mrow><mn>2</mn><mi>a</mi></mrow></mfrac></math>. Substituting the values: <math xmlns='http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML'><mi>x</mi><mo>=</mo><mo>-</mo><mfrac><mn>4</mn><mrow><mn>2</mn><mo>(</mo><mn>1</mn><mo>)</mo></mrow></mfrac><mo>=</mo><mo>-</mo><mn>2</mn></math>.
questions.score_improvement_tip: For any quadratic function <math xmlns='http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML'><mi>a</mi><msup><mi>x</mi><mn>2</mn></msup><mo>+</mo><mi>b</mi><mi>x</mi><mo>+</mo><mi>c</mi></math>, the extremum (minimum or maximum) always occurs at the vertex <math xmlns='http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML'><mi>x</mi><mo>=</mo><mo>-</mo><mfrac><mi>b</mi><mrow><mn>2</mn><mi>a</mi></mrow></mfrac></math>.

questions.skill: Probability and conditional probability
questions.question: In a survey of <math xmlns='http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML'><mn>100</mn></math> people, <math xmlns='http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML'><mn>60</mn></math> respondents stated they like apples and <math xmlns='http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML'><mn>50</mn></math> stated they like bananas. If <math xmlns='http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML'><mn>30</mn></math> people indicated they like both apples and bananas, how many people in the survey liked neither fruit?
questions.explanation: To find the number of people who like neither, first calculate the number of people who like at least one fruit using the Principle of Inclusion-Exclusion: <math xmlns='http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML'><mi>n</mi><mo>(</mo><mi>A</mi><mo>∪</mo><mi>B</mi><mo>)</mo><mo>=</mo><mi>n</mi><mo>(</mo><mi>A</mi><mo>)</mo><mo>+</mo><mi>n</mi><mo>(</mo><mi>B</mi><mo>)</mo><mo>-</mo><mi>n</mi><mo>(</mo><mi>A</mi><mo>∩</mo><mi>B</mi><mo>)</mo></math>. Substituting the given values: <math xmlns='http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML'><mn>60</mn><mo>+</mo><mn>50</mn><mo>-</mo><mn>30</mn><mo>=</mo><mn>80</mn></math>. This means <math xmlns='http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML'><mn>80</mn></math> people like at least one of the fruits. Finally, subtract this from the total population to find those who like neither: <math xmlns='http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML'><mn>100</mn><mo>-</mo><mn>80</mn><mo>=</mo><mn>20</mn></math>.
questions.score_improvement_tip: When dealing with overlapping sets, remember to subtract the intersection (the 'both' category) so you don't count it twice.
